"But it isn't original."  No story is truly original.  Even Shakespeare heavily borrowed elements from previous plays.  Black clover puts enough of a spin onthe genre that it stands alone. Anime of a battle shounen of Weekly Shounen Jump. Black Clover shouts this phrase in every way, from the personalities of the characters, motivational shocking phrases, to the comic bias and action fights full of special powers, without doubt the main characteristic that accompanies the successes of the genre. The story follows the journey of twoorphans named Asta and Yuno heading to their dreams of being the Wizard King (the supreme and most powerful Wizard figure) in a world where magic is absolutely everything.


Though full of those cloying clichés that haunt almost every major production of the popular battle shounens, such as a teeming show of friendship, friendly rivalry, a certain background drama and main character with noble intentions and brave heart, we can not rule out the fact that such characteristics are essential and need to be shown before the age of the target audience: children and young people (especially boys aged 9 to 15, true devourers of that kind series).


With the adaptation for anime, Black Clover gained something of great importance that, in its original material, the manga, was almost totally left out: the development and deepening in the history of the characters. The director earns points in showing through the hated fillers (that plays a very good and necessary role here, although some are purposely elongated to fill the minutes of the episode), the past of the characters in a way that the viewer creates a bond affective much larger than the existing one in the manga series. In it, Yuuki Tabata, original creator of the work, sins a lot in this respect, showing his immaturity as a writer in presenting these elements (which could be constructed in a much more worked, without the horrible characteristic hurry of the illustrated work) so important in three or four pages.


Speaking of Yoshihara Tatsuya, it is impossible to talk about anime animation without mentioning it. Tatsuya is an experienced and recognized animator (much more competent in this area than as a director, a profession in which he still needs to improve), and although he is not directly involved with the artistic direction itself, his contact list is full of names extremely efficient. After all, what can we expect from an anime in which the director has already been key animator of such series as Ano Hana and Arakawa Under the Bridge x Bridge? Of course, wonderful footage and some breathtaking action scenes, far above the average of almost all fighting animes from recent years (citing, especially, points from episode 01, 02, 04, 06 and 10, striking with wonderful sakuga) .


And it is, even under his influence, that we have reached the point of greatest prominence of this first part of Black Clover: the ending. Dismissing the song comments (made by the duo Itowokashi, which had already been perfect in Sousei on Onmyouji, and here do not let the quality fall), it is all directed, scripted and animated by the prodigy animator Ryu Nakama. Both he and Tatsuya are youngsters of the same generation and have worked together in the past, culminating in a special invitation for the ending of this was done by Ryu. Watching or not anime, it is more than recommended that you go check this wonderful production. A pity to have only a minute and a half.


The soundtrack is also correct and striking in strategic moments, making the hype present and rising as the viewer gets excited about what they are watching. And since the subject is the sounds, how to not mention one of the points that most caused dissatisfaction to the public? Yes, I'm talking about the voice actors (specifically, one voice actor).


Popular figures of great talent and renown are present in the team, such as Nobunaga Shimazaki (Nanase Haruka of Free!) And Fukuyama Jun (Lelouch Lamperouge of Code Geass), but the center of attention, and unfortunately not in a positive way, is the inexperienced Kajiwara Gakuto, interpreter of the Asta. His screams that are three times more constant than necessary have an extremely loud and aching sound to the ears, a fact that makes the character memorable and unique, even if not in the positive way that we would like. Here, it is not the voice that does not match the character (because it is perfect for him) or the intonations are not applied correctly, but rather the volume in the sound control is extremely high and the actor's sharp note, when shouting, "dirty" way. If you endure the first three episodes, there is a noticeable reduction in volume and number of cries, and your ears will be at least almost accustomed.


Black Clover is an anime without any innovation, animation bordering the perfection in the first two episodes, but with inconsistent quality in the remaining, characters that fulfill what is expected from a battle shounen. For the 10 episodes seen, little actually developed and the supposed real villains gave a cool background at the end of the last one, in that old and good intention of making the public curious about what will happen next.


Above all, the series is a perfect commercial move (being blatantly treated as "epic adventure" in the trailers, by high publicity and investment) to work and become the worldwide success that is today, remembering that it's manga premiered purposely shortly after the end of NARUTO, taking full advantage of its similar vibe and catching the orphaned fans of the show. Advisable to those who want an authentic and pure fighting anime, without complex dialogues or plot twists unimaginable.

Anime de um battle shounen da Weekly Shounen Jump. Black Clover grita essa frase de todas as formas, desde as personalidades de seus personagens, frases impactantes motivacionais, passando pelo ligeiro viés cômico e pela ação com lutas repletas de poderes especiais, sem dúvidas a característica principal que acompanha os sucessos do gênero. A história segue a jornada de dois órfãos chamados Asta e Yuno rumo aos seus sonhos de serem o Rei Mago (a figura suprema e mais poderosa de mago) em um mundo onde magia é absolutamente tudo.


Apesar de repleto daqueles enjoativos clichês que assombram quase toda grande produção dos tão populares battle shounen, como a demonstração farta de amizade, rivalidade amigável, certo drama em segundo plano e personagem principal que possui nobres intenções e coração valente, não podemos excluir o fato de que tais características são essenciais e precisam ser mostradas perante a idade do público-alvo: as crianças e jovens (em especial os garotos de 9 a 15 anos, verdadeiros devoradores de séries como essa).


Com a adaptação para anime, Black Clover ganhou algo de grande importância que, em seu material original, o mangá, era quase que totalmente deixado de lado: o desenvolvimento e aprofundamento na história dos personagens. O diretor ganha pontos em mostrar, através dos tão odiados fillers (mas que cumprem um papel muito bom e necessário aqui, apesar de alguns serem propositalmente alongados para preencher os minutos do episódio), o passado dos personagens de maneira que o telespectador crie um vínculo afetivo muito maior do que o existente na série em quadrinhos. Nela, Yuuki Tabata, criador original da obra, peca e muito nesse quesito, mostrando sua imaturidade como roteirista ao apresentar esses elementos (que poderiam ser construídos de forma muito mais trabalhada, sem a horrível pressa característica da obra ilustrada) tão importantes em três ou quatro páginas.


Falando em Yoshihara Tatsuya, é impossível falar da animação do anime sem citá-lo. Tatsuya é um experiente e reconhecido animador (muito mais competente nessa área do que como diretor, profissão em que ainda precisa se aprimorar), e por mais que não esteja diretamente envolvido com a direção artística em si, sua lista de contatos é repleta de nomes extremamente eficientes. Afinal, o que podemos esperar de um anime em que o diretor já foi key animator de séries como Ano Hana e Arakawa Under the Bridge x Bridge? Claro, imagens maravilhosas e algumas cenas de ação de tirar o fôlego, muito acima da média de quase todos animes de luta dos últimos anos (citando, especialmente, passagens do episódio 01, 02, 04, 06 e 10, marcantes com maravilhosos sakuga).


E é, ainda por influência dele, que chegamos ao ponto de maior destaque dessa primeira parte de Black Clover: O encerramento. Dispensando comentários sobre a música (feita pelo dueto Itowokashi, que já haviam sido perfeitos em Sousei no Onmyouji, e aqui não deixam a qualidade cair), ele é todo dirigido, roteirizado e animado pelo animador prodígio Ryu Nakama. Tanto ele quanto Tatsuya são jovens da mesma geração e que trabalharam juntos no passado, culminando assim, num convite especial para que o encerramento desse fosse feito por Ryu. Assistindo ou não ao anime, é mais do que recomendável que você vá conferir essa maravilhosa produção. Uma pena possuir apenas um minuto e meio.


A trilha sonora também é correta e se mostra marcante em momentos estratégicos, fazendo com que o hype se faça presente e se eleve na medida com que o espectador se empolgar com o que está assistindo. E já que o assunto são os sons, como deixar de citar um dos pontos que mais causaram insatisfação ao público? Sim, estou falando dos dubladores (em específico, de um dublador).


Figuras populares de grande talento e renome estão presentes na equipe, como Nobunaga Shimazaki (Nanase Haruka de Free!) e Fukuyama Jun (Lelouch Lamperouge de Code Geass), mas o centro das atenções, e infelizmente não de uma forma positiva, é o inexperiente Kajiwara Gakuto, interpretante do Asta. Seus gritos triplamente mais constantes que o necessário possuem um som extremamente elevado e dolorido aos ouvidos, fato que torna o personagem memorável e único, mesmo que não da maneira positiva que gostaríamos. Aqui, não se trata da voz não combinar com o personagem (pois é perfeita para ele) ou as entonações não serem aplicadas corretamente, mas sim do volume no controle de som ser extremamente elevado e da nota aguda do ator, ao gritar, sair de maneira tão “suja”. Caso aguente os três primeiros episódios, há uma notória redução no volume e na quantidade de gritos, além de que seus ouvidos já estarão, pelo menos, quase que acostumados.


Black Clover é um anime sem nenhuma inovação, animação beirando a perfeição nos dois primeiros episódios, mas com qualidade inconsistente nos restantes e personagens que cumprem o que se espera de um battle shounen. Pelos 10 episódios vistos, pouco realmente se desenvolveu e os supostos verdadeiros vilões deram um background legal no final do último, naquela velha e boa intenção de deixar o público curioso com o que acontecerá mais pra frente.


Acima de tudo, a série é uma perfeita jogada comercial (sendo descaradamente tratada como “épica aventura” nos trailers, pela alta divulgação e investimento) para que funcionasse e se tornasse o sucesso mundial que é hoje, lembrando que seu mangá estreou propositalmente pouco após o final de NARUTO, aproveitando totalmente sua vibe semelhante e pegando os fãs órfãos da obra. Aconselhável àqueles que querem um autêntico e puro anime de luta, sem diálogos complexos ou plot twists inimagináveis.

I'd like to preface this by stating that this is the first anime review I've ever written, but after reading a few reviews post-finishing the currently aired episodes (64), I felt the need to contribute. During my time watching Black Clover (that time being under a week, as I did binge watch the series) I overall found it a decently enjoyable series, one that I will most definitely continue. Like other reviewers I've read, I don't think it is fair to compare Black Clover to and base its credibility on other anime. While Black Clover shares similarities in plot, character tropes, and stereotypical genre qualitieswith other popular shonen, such as Fairy Tail and Naruto, it is very likely that this is due to the popularity and success of the aforementioned (both the shows and their repeating characteristics). Even if this were not the case, the recycling of the qualities does not necessarily make the show bad. 


Onto the story, which I gave a 7 for good. The plot revolving around Asta's dream and wholesome rivalry with his childhood friend Yuno is one I enjoy, being it essentially requires the story line to revolve around the character development of not only Asta, but also of Yuno, and their competition. Through this we get to see not only Asta and Yuno develop, but many of their comrades. The underdog story line, while common, never feels to get too old, and with this, Black Clover brings an interesting approach to it with its multiple scenarios in which the under dog rises (one I especially like in the case of Noelle). Aside from those, I did find the fight scenes to be too drawn out, as the antagonists seem to suffer from mild plot armor just for the benefit of the protagonists more than a utilized furthering of plot, becoming somewhat tiresome. However, I did find the class difference effects on perspective of physique and lifestyle a tad bit surprising, in a good way. The show, reflecting reality, depicts the higher class scorning the hard work and low magic of the lower classes, multiple remarks being made on Asta's physique being unappealing and gross (which may also just be a part of Japanese culture) with him being low born. While this may not be particularly ground breaking, it was intriguing enough to provide decent food for thought. The questions and interest I garnered from plot alone was enough for me to find it good, while it still being not outstanding because of the mediocrity in excitement and satisfaction through the battle scenes, which tend to be long for the major fights.


I gave both art and sound a 6. While I enjoyed the animation in the battle scenes, it seemed to lack throughout non essential parts, noticeably enough that it could tend to become visually displeasing, particularly if you are someone that values the artwork of an anime. I will admit to being fairly irritated at the beginning of this series with the voice acting of Asta(sub). The constant yelling of the main character was, at first, an audible nuisance, however, as the show went on it turned into being more endearing and comedic as we get closer to Asta's character. In all, I didn't find any of the voice acting particularly moving at any point in time, but did enjoy how some of the voice actors really personified their character through their voice (Magna being a personal favorite).


Both character and enjoyment received a 9, or great, from me. The characters would have to be my favorite part about Black Clover, and really pick up in places the story itself can be lacking. I particularly enjoy the development of Asta and Yuno's teammates, because it creates more dynamic characters, and I personally enjoy learning about their diversified struggles, mindsets, backgrounds, and even magic. There were very few characters that I disliked, and even in those characters, there were qualities and behaviors that made me want to know more about them. Individually, each character is fairly well rounded, and I love watching the teammates and friends of the main characters grow and develop alongside them. This highly contributes to my enjoyment the show.


I'm not very picky with the anime I watch and what I like. I enjoy pretty much any show with a decent story line and fun characters. That being said, I am no anime elitist, nor do I really analyze the anime I watch. However, Black Clover provided both decent story line with fun characters, and intrigue that made me think while watching the show. This affected my watching and enjoyment, as it did drive me to continue on with the show with an increased vigor. Combining this with my love of the characters, fantasy settings, and the evolving story line, I very much so enjoy Black Clover.


All in all, I rate Black Clover, so far, with a 7, or a good. While in my heart it's more of an 8, because of how much I did enjoy the show, realistically it is closer to a 7 because of the somewhat mediocre story line, as well as the okay art and decent sound. The hate Black Clover receives is kind of understandable, but could most likely be avoided if it wasn't held to the standard of other more successful and popular anime. I am excited to see where the show will go, and hope that Black Clover makes a name uniquely for itself.

OK ish...where to start for Black Clover...hmm..."The new Shounen for a new generation (just like Boruto)..." oh wait, Studio Pierrot...the masters of Shounen anime for decades past with the Big 3 and aiming for the same result with this and Boruto? Absolutely NOT working.
Getting the sense out of watching something like this, it's no stranger to overhate and fuzzy-loving people, comparing to the decade earlier with the big 3 anime (Naruto, Bleach, Fairy Tail (should I add One Piece also?)).
Not even the prior realization that from a 1 cour 12 episode to a 4 cour 51 episode count (like Sousei no Onmyouji which was alsodone by Pierrot) could save the production.


So, with 20% done (10 out of 51 episodes), how does it compare to the production values and the manga adaptation?


In a word: CHEAP. Abso-tainting-utely mediocre and painfully slow. But in all honesty, with the Shounen treatment that Studio Pierrot has done over the years, a little bit of credit is due. That's not to say that I like this show or not, it's just that over on YouTube and forums everywhere, this has been covered a million-over times and I cannot emphasize this enough.


So, with Episode 10 out of the way, I've gotta say that the story AT LEAST is back on track like a proper pacing episode, and it's by far the best episode with the same "meh" conditions that plagued the first 20% of the show, and actually am a bit excited about how the progression will live on towards the remaining 40 episodes (since this is a 4-cour anime), but expectations will vary.


The art and animation are really the same quality as what Pierrot unleashes nowadays, just standard but nice sorta cel-shading art to cover the inequalities of the manga adaptation.


The OST however is another story. Aside from Asta's VA (or CV for otakus) (which is a newbie), I'd say that while his character stands out the most, earlier on it's all for the wrong reasons, and combine with the show's pacing, it's no wonder why people who watch this show give up almost immediately. But as I've said, give the show a second chance to deliver, and opinions may vary, but it's each and everyone's call. The other VAs did an OK job in delivering the show's aspects, and they're the usual Pierrot standard. The OP and ED are not horrible honestly, and is really quite catchy that sets the mood for the new-fangled Shounen troupe.


But then again, it's up to Studio Pierrot to live up the standards of what make the Big 3 standout in the past decade, and to copy that tried-and-true formula into making Black Clover from a horrible, slow-starting show to one that is at least decent to viewers (or fans) of the Big 3 (especially Naruto since the formula is spoiler alert)


This review only pertains to the 1st 10 episodes, and I'm gonna release every progressive review from every 10 eps down to cover every new cour's offerings.


For now, blessed are those who watch (or dropped) Black Clover and your hate is overdue and your love is shallow. Either way, love or hate it, it's just a show with decent, if not mediocre production.

The subbed version is nearly unwatchable due to the voice acting of the main character. The way he screams every five seconds that he's on screen in the same high-pitched tone is, while impressive on the part of the voice actor, highly annoying. It's almost like they just copied and pasted the same scream in over and over again. The dubbed version offers an easier watch. There are going to be a lot of familiar voices, but they're much easier on the ears. The story so far is bland and mediocre at best. Many have said that a comparison can be made to the originalNaruto series, and they're not wrong. The unpopular character wants to become the leader, he has a dark-haired rival who excels at everything that he does not making him a prodigy, they grew up together, they're orphans, and he is stubborn to the point of idiocy. As the story progresses, he utilizes the "power of friendship" to defeat seemingly invincible enemies, all while getting seriously hurt in the process. The stereotypical character tropes abound in this anime. You have the tsundere (a couple of them, in fact), the loner, the sis-con, the drunk hot chick who always makes suggestive remarks, the scary leader, the tiny girl who eats like an elephant and is entirely controlled by food, the hothead, the happy battle-freak, the fat guy, the quiet creepy guy who's actually probably friendly but everyone still ignores, the "ladies' man" who isn't really liked by the ladies, the arrogant jerk who turns out to be caring and overprotective, the elitists, the whiny King, the childhood crush who rejects the main character, children who are entirely too realistic and intelligent for their age, the ex-goodguy, the over-powered good guy who is nearly killed shortly after revealing how "powerful" he is, the mad scientist/crazy doctor girl with an obsession over dissecting and experimenting on the main character, the serious guy, the serious girl, the girl who says very lesbian-esque things, the tomboy, the powerful old lady, the crazy witch who steals people's youth and wants people to tell her she's "beautiful" but goes absolutely insane when someone calls her "old", the mysterious leader, the reptilian leader, the sleepy leader, the wise leader, the muscle leader, the serious leader, the somewhat shady leader, the silent leader, the scarred bad guy, the laughing bad guy, the laughing-while-being-useless good guy, the tough guy, the weak guy, the sad guy, the happy guy, the innocent little girl, the mischievous little boy, nearly EVERYONE expect for a few characters have ridiculously stupid hair and/or outfits just to make them unique and stand out, and dozens more that I've yet to uncover or have simply lost track of. Every character has to shout the name of their spells whenever they cast them, which gets aggravating. But the most heinous, most infuriating, most unforgivable trend that this anime follows is the flashback/recap trend. Almost every episode has at least two to four minutes of recaps from the previous episode along with innumerable flashbacks in the most aggravating places. Everyone has some kind of backstory and traumatic history. A typical episode is 20% recaps, 20% flashbacks, 10% talking about how friendship is the key to winning, 15% screaming, 15% characters thinking about how something is "amazing", "incredible", "impossible", or "unbelievable", 10% powering-up, 5% power move failure, 3% gasping, 1% action, and 1% plot progression. If you cut out the internal monologues, flashbacks, recaps, gasping, stares of disbelief, repeatedly failed attacks, side-stories, and action-background moves, you MIGHT have one or two decent fight scenes. The fact that this anime is getting 50+ episodes is pathetic. A full season of 26 episodes would've been more than enough had they cut out all the unnecessary bullsh*t and actually progressed the story. Then again, you can probably blame the commercial success of series like Naruto or Dragonball for carbon-copied animes such as this. However, even the studio behind Naruto and Dragonball eventually realized these mistakes and improved. I could see this series being popular during the late 90's/early 2000's, but in 2018 these mistakes are simply inexcusable. The constant explanations of why "this move is impossible to block and is going to defeat you no matter what" that ultimately fail, almost without failure, make even mediocre stories seem drawn out and overblown. Every character has one or two moves that they rely on constantly and are almost without exception weak and make no difference in a fight. The final blows are almost always physical and mostly non-lethal, regardless of how hard they hit. Sword slashes rarely produce a serious wound. The production is spotty, too. There are a few scenes where you can tell they cheaped-out on the still shots because of the cost of animating action. You suddenly go from consistent, somewhat mediocre art, to disproportionate faces/heads that hardly resemble the character and look like they were drawn by the studio's interns/trainees/amateurs. There is too much filler/dialogue and not enough action and story progression. There is a great deal of comic relief in the unfiltered comments of one of the leaders, but this show's main plot does not revolve around this character, unfortunately. I honestly feel sorry for the manga artist because this anime is going to make people hate this series. I'm not sure how popular this series is, but it's a huge miss for me.

Story: 5
I don't care whether or not it's "just another shounen," or if the manga is better, or if it's better to watch weekly or in one big session.  The story is starting out at "okay" and promises to get a little better as time goes on and new elements of the plot and character abilities are revealed; as a shounen often does.  It's meant to be stuck with for the long-haul, and I'm okay with that.
With that said, I can't give the story a better score for now because, well, it's just not good.  Black Clover the anime has undoubtedly hammeredin its ideas of classism and "Magic is EVERYTHING in this world," but that's about as far as we've gotten in what is supposed to be a fast-paced story.  21 episodes in, so far, and precious little has progressed in the overall narrative.  I really think the word "peasant" will continue to be used as a slur in this show at least until the first big time skip.


Art: 3

The animation is bad.  Like, Berserk (2016) bad.  I literally can't go 3 minutes per episode without thinking "how can the art be this lackluster?"  Basic movements like eating, speaking, casual gestures, they're as minimal as can be, as far as I can tell.  But when it comes time to ramp up the action, OH BOY LOOK OUT, sometimes they use god-awful smoke effects that look like shadowy low-res FMVs from 1997!  How about those wind effects on that mighty wind magic?  Boy howdy, sometimes they draw more than 2 frames of a whirlwind, ain't that a treat!

The art is bad, possibly one of the worst parts of the anime so far.  It isn't slick like Bleach or Naruto; it isn't unique like One Piece; it isn't risque like Fairy Tail, it doesn't quite have the character diversity like Hunter X Hunter.  There's no charm to any of the designs, no visual flair that makes it a joy to watch.  

I genuinely wonder where the production budget went, because clearly the art wasn't even close to high priority.

Black Clover might be infamous for its voice work, but even that has tapered off to tolerable; the art and animation, however, has a long, LONG way to go to properly improve.

Now, think of the music in Black Clover.  Go on, try to really cudgel your brain for this one.  Not nearly as simple, is it?  The music is forgettable, and I would argue that that's WORSE than being outright BAD.

As of this review, I've seen 20 episodes of the anime, aswell as read to the same point in the manga (around chapter 24). Most of the top reviews on this page haven't gotten past 10 episodes, and I realise that if they didn't enjoy then they're probably gonna stop, but in my opinion Black Clove has really turned things around. Black Clover has garnered a bad reputation due to it's clearly bad start, but particularly from the beginning of the dungeon arc onwards (about episode 13 or 14) there has been a pretty huge leap in quality.
Story - 8
I mean, if you like yourtypical shounen setup you're gonna enjoy Black Clover. For me, I've found the super long series such as Naruto and One Piece extremely difficult to catch up on due to the very slow pace and huge amount of content to get through. Black Clover's unique quality is the extreme fast pace, compared to other shounen anime. A typical arc that could take 15 chapters in the likes of Naruto takes 3 or less in Black Clover. It uses the cliches of the genre to it's advantage, it understands that the reader can fill in the blanks and not everything needs to be gone over, as everyone knows the tropes of shounen at this point. If you enjoy My Hero Academia, I'd feel you'd enjoy this, the setups are pretty similar, a hero with no powers in a world where everyone has different abilities. In this, it's magic rather than quirks. I won't disassemble the story, but if you like shounen you'd definitely enjoy this. Oh, the studio was obsessed with filler for the first like 12 episodes, so i'd reccomend looking up which episodes can be skipped. Since the pace is so fast, they tried to slow it down by adding lots of extra scenes and expanding on flashbacks which do nothing for the story and bring the story to a halt (at one point we were at 1 chapter spread over 3 episodes), but now we have gotten to a point where it is about 2 chapters per episode which is perfect if you ask me.


Art - 5 (before episode 14, could be a 4 or 3, nearer to episode 20 it could be a 5.5/6)

The artwork is extremely lazy at first. Constant reuse of animation, constant recaps just to save time on the episode (recaps often up to 5 minutes), and very poorly implemented special effects for the first arc. There is a pretty big jump in quality at the dungeon arc, but it's jumping from bad to average (and slightly above average in fights), so I can understand that art is not a selling point, and it never really is in a long running series like this.


Sound - 6

Just a typical shounen soundtrack, I thoroughly enjoy the EDs and OPs though, and particularly the little changes they make in the OPs to represent whats going on in the story, which is a nice little thing to notice. There's been many complaints about Asta's voice actor, about his extremely annoying voice which i AGREE is an issue, but this is the VA's big break. He's made huge leaps and bounds of improvement in later episodes, and he deserves to be commended.


Character - 7

The main characters are all very likeable, there's not one Black Bull I dislike, and their unique magic styles are very interesting to learn about as well as their backstories. The villains are typical for a shounen, Mars is literally Zabuza from Naruto, but they're not the focus. The focus here is on teamwork combat, which i think is done amazingly, and all these characters have good chemistry.


Enjoyment - 8

I personally really enjoy it, although if shounen is not your thing you definitely wont.


Overall, I'd give it a 7. It had some difficulties at the start but it's really made improvements and i can acknowledge that.

There is certainly something to be said about anime based on popular shonen jump manga. The fastest word that comes to mind is intrigue. This, to me, is the best way to explain one of jump’s latest adaptations Black Clover. 
Black Clover’s overall all design is not that fascinating to me in terms of characters. It would seem that the personalities of each character play a bigger role in terms of likability than their look or even abilities. Like Naruto, the studio is choosing when to go all in on the animation and so far I do not have too many complaints in this department.

One can certainly argue that Black Clover falls under the same formulaic troupes that have produced some of the most iconic anime to date. Even with that said, it manages to bring something different to the table and I believe that is where the draw to this title lies.


Black Clover follows Asta an abandoned orphan found along side Yuno his would be rival in the story. Asta lives in a world surrounded by the power of magic with dreams of becoming the wizard king, a position started by a legendary hero who saved the world from eminent ruin, there is only one problem, he has no magic abilities.


Despite this apparent set back, a latent ability hidden within Asta unveils a powerful weapon that has the ability to negate magic turning his fate around and basically taking us on his journey to become the aforementioned wizard king.


While Asta’s character is probably the most unpleasant main character I’ve had the experience of listening to due to his obnoxious and intentional atrocious voice acting(a first experience in my book), it is his actions and obvious ambitions that grow on you to the point you ignore it after a while. 


Of course, it’s not only Asta that keeps my interest. Like most Jump anime’s, it is the characters that surround Asta with their mysterious abilities, motivations, and more importantly, their disdain for what Asta represents that continue to pull on you as you watch further. 


The soundtrack has not had anything that stood out to me. It doesn’t to seem to give or take away from the anime in anyway though I have enjoyed the two opening songs they have offered up thus far.


Black Clover certainly has a long way to go but in terms of what the anime has shown to date, I have to be honest and say: so far, so good.  For all of its hang ups, there is heart in this anime which is what has me compelled to continue watching and that is what’s important at the end of the day.

Hyped as the next big thing in shounen anime by some, Black Clover is the story of Asta and Yuno, two boys who were abandoned at a church on the same day. As they grow up, the unlikely duo develop a heated rivalry and vow to best each other in their like-minded ambition to become the next Wizard King. Yuno, the clear favourite to emerge victorious, is reserved and highly competent, even having a rare and powerful Grimoire bestowed upon him when he turns 15. Asta, on the other hand, is loud and utterly inept at magic, but receives a similar blessing in the formof an even rarer "five-leaf clover" Grimoire. Set on their diverging paths to greatness, the adopted brothers must work their way up in the new world of magic that they find waiting for them outside of the church.


Aesthetically, Black Clover is decent, but certainly nothing ground-breaking. The artstyle fits the medieval European flair it seems to be going for well, and lends the series a grittier, more rustic feel compared to shows of a similar vein like Fairy Tail, which is much more upbeat and colourful.


Character designs feel a bit bland and unoriginal, lacking a much-needed quality to prevent themselves from appearing too "shounen-y." The leading duo of Asta and Yuno look way too similar to their counterparts in other shounen anime such as Naruto and Fairy Tail. Which is unfortunate, considering Black Clover should be doing as much as humanly possible to distinguish itself from the giants whose footprints it so stubbornly insists on following.


Excepting the fact that there haven't been that many fights of note so far, the animation has remained solid. For a show of this length (51 episodes), it will be interesting to see if the animation eventually falls apart by the time it reaches the finish line, or if it'll manage to surprise and keep a high level of quality all throughout.


To keep things simple, Black Clover does not have a good protagonist. Asta is an exact clone of the typical knuckle-headed, high-energy shounen hero, with the added baggage of being obnoxiously loud and persistent. He is in no way original or likeable, and neither is Yuno, who is a straight-up copy-and-paste of the introverted, yet incredibly gifted childhood rival archetype.


It is too early to make any sort of decision on the rest of the cast, but one thing that was painfully evident about the Black Bulls was that their introductions and characterization were blatantly similar to those of the Fairy Tail Guild in Fairy Tail. This is another aspect of the show that feels much too similar to the shounen giants that it should be competing with. For a shounen anime so late in the game, Black Clover really should be investing its energy in shaking up the formula shounen fans have grown so accustomed to, or at least making the ride a bit more fun and unique.


The story is, so far, nothing surprising for a shounen anime. Plenty of flashbacks, high-soaring ambitions, and snippets of action are present from beginning to end, yet the major weakness in terms of narrative is not managing to get the audience behind the characters' motivations. Asta is so annoying and Yuno so guarded that it is difficult to really find yourself cheering them on or feeling their pain. The new characters that are slowly piled on may present a solution to this, however, as they are coming across more likeable and diverse than the initial two, as would some meaningful character development for Asta.


Your own personal enjoyment of this show will come down to how willing you are to watch a standard shounen anime with not much to offer in terms of new ideas. Fans of the shows it so closely mimics, namely Naruto and Fairy Tail, may find themselves unable to take Black Clover seriously as its own separate experience, and inevitably make an unflattering comparison to the aforementioned titles.


Someone really pining for a more recent shounen anime may find the familiar story developments and archetypal characters comforting and satisfying in a way, but only if they are truly desperate for something so characteristically shounen. When the anime adaptation was first announced, a lot of people were calling it a "magic-themed Naruto" and after watching the first cour, I can confirm that this is a totally-justified claim. If that sounds like it would be right up your alley, then this show will likely be an enjoyable experience. If not, I would say it's probably going to be the complete opposite.


Taking into account the endless screaming on Asta's part, the overreliance on tired tropes, and a general failure to bring anything new to the table, Black Clover is not something easy to recommend this early in its run. That is, unless what you are looking for is a new shounen anime to watch after having seen all of the firmly-established titles.


If it manages to keep up its solid animation, develop Asta and Yuno in meaningful ways, and bank on the strengths of its genre's tropes, while also changing them up and doing more to distinguish itself from its predecessors, Black Clover may end up becoming a show worth watching, but if, and only if.

I feel like this show got off to a slow start, and even was honestly mediocre early on; however, the show gets better as the story progresses into a solid Shonen anime. Which is understandable since these kind of shows are designed to have dozens and dozens of episodes over a planned 12-24 episode series.
I digress, but Asta doesn't join the Black Bulls until episode 6, and he doesn't on his first mission until about episode 8 or9. We literally take 4-5 hours just to get on our first adventure beyond the training/intro phrase, and it wasn't paced well. That said, the first mission is okay, but nothing memorable. What really turns the series around is the Dunegon arc which isn't too long, but reintroduces Asta with his old friend and rival, Yuno. And we see multiple people form two different groups working together to overcome their challenges, and it works well. From here the show really gains momentum and becomes a solid show. Especially the Seabed Temple Arc which closes out season 1. 


For me, and possibly others, the show takes about 13-14 episodes to turn the page into something enjoyable. The major strength of this show as it moves forward is establishing multiple characters with interesting and unique backgrounds, and they all have to come together to overcome their challenges. I also like Asta, but the show was weak only relying on him without a strong support cast in most episodes. The pacing improves, and even longer arcs are enjoyable and at a good pace.


Finally, the animation and sound design is good. I won't say it's groundbreaking, or the most beautiful thing I've seen, but it's smooth with some good action scenes. Some action scenes stand out better than others, but it's typical when it comes to a shonen anime. I say give this a chance, but you have to be patient to see if you like it after a good 14 episodes.

Story- 5/10
The story has drawn many comparisons to other popular series, including Naruto, My Hero Academia, Fairy Tail, and even Harry Potter. As a result, it has also drawn the ire of shonen fans. To a degree, deservedly so; some aspects are not original. They are a group of ragtag mages part of a guild- I mean shinobis- I mean wizards- er, magic knights. The protagonist, Asta, wants to become the hokage- I mean wizard king…because he wants to prove to everyone how capable he is and help people…or something.
There are some good things that the story does which your other typical shonen do notdo. First, this story thankfully moves faster than any of the other shonen mentioned. The “Zabuza” arc was over in two episodes. The Chunin/Quirk Hero tournament/exam was over in two episodes. The speed at which it moves is good. It maintains it’s fluidity and moves things right along, cutting out at least some of your typical shonen bullcrap. IE “Let me give a speech about my powers and how awesome I am for 10 minutes before doing anything, then lets do something and talk about it afterwards for another 5 minutes. End of episode!” The middle 10 episodes or so of this series does have a bit of this unfortunately. Thankfully, that was the only part that dragged. 


Another underrated aspect is that characters other than the strong adults and protagonist actually do meaningful things to main antagonists. So two strong mages are fighting- It’s going to be an epic clash between the two all the way to the finish line, right? Nah, one of the scrub minions will interfere with his unique ability, defeating the antagonist boss instead. Well, what about another, stronger antagonist boss later? One that wrecks through most of the protagonist squad without so much as a scratch? Well, the main heroine- who had done little in the series previously- wrecks him. And consider this- within the first 46 episodes of their respective series, did Sakura, Ochako, or Lucy pull off any amazing feat that comparable characters could not do? Within that time frame, did any of them do anything meaningful to an overwhelming antagonist that even the protagonist could not (initially) do?  I’d wager not.


Those two moments mentioned above weren’t complete asspulls either, contrary to what you’d expect. For the former, his unique ability countered the unique ability of the boss reasonably. For the latter, she was hinted at having extraordinary magic attack power but previously had not been able to utilize it properly due to her mindset.


Of course some asspull powerups are still there (A mage in an intense situation can develop new spells). I wish shonen would be better at writing that, instead of always chalking it up as “willpower+ friendship = insta win hurr durr.” The worldbuilding could be better too.



Art- 7/10


While it can be inconsistent at times, the quality is never poor. At it’s worst it’s average, and at it’s best it’s pretty darn good. For a 51 episode series this is a good sign.


Sound- 8/10


The most redeemable aspect of the series is the sound. The dub version is great. Most of the OST is good, including the openings and endings. There is one song in particular which is particularly epic. The reason this category loses points is because the sub version of the protagonist has a really grating voice. The high-pitched, constant screaming will make your ears bleed. The dub version is mostly superior for this reason, and I heartily recommend that one.


Character- 5/10


Many of the characters are cutouts from your standard archetypes, and as a result, many of them are boring and uninteresting. Some of them are given backstories, such as Luck and Gauche. Yet that didn’t make them any more interesting, either. They were still rather one-dimensional characters with unoriginal backstories.


Of course there are a few hidden gems here. Noelle, the main heroine, is your typical Tsundere early on in the series and is usually relegated to protecting the wounded. But later in the series, she has a completely boss moment where she almost completely owns a strong antagonist. This antagonist had decimated every other strong fighter there- including the protagonist, Asta. It was the first demonstration of her true strength, and I look forward to seeing her in the future. She developed into a great female lead.


In Asta’s case, he does have your typical “Nice guy, Loudmouth who never gives up with no talent” cliché, but the unique thing about him at least is his power. He has no magic power you see, and instead must rely on his unique ability. That is, he can cancel other magic. This is actually fairly neat.  Typically while protagonists are “losers in life” such as with Naruto and Deku and even Natsu to a degree, their skillset is also typically the same. They all summon up enormous power through sheer will and training to overpower opponents.  Their skills themselves aren’t particularly unique in how they are utilized. In Black Clover’s case, while Asta does have high physical abilities, he is mostly relying on the skill itself- not raw power like most other protagonists.  In this regard, I at least appreciate that aspect of Asta.


The other character I should talk about is Yuno. He also draws many comparisons to characters such as Sasuke and Shouto/Katsuki, and to a degree, rightfully so. Yet there are also a couple key things that set him apart. Foremost, while he is a declared “rival” of the protagonist, the two were also very good friends their entire lives, akin to brothers even. Contrast that with Sasuke and Naruto who hated each other at first, and the uncaring, cold attitude Shouto/Katsuki share towards Deku. Also, while Yuno had natural magical talent when he was young, he was also a complete wimp and even a bit of loser. His admiration towards Asta made him change that eventually. Another contrast to the typical “cool” characters other shonens put forth.


So while the cast as a whole is hardly worth any ringing endorsements, there are a few characteristics among the main cast that can be appreciated. There are also a lot of side characters in this show, most of whom I can’t remember their names but their faces are easy to recognize, so some credit is due there to I suppose.



Enjoyment- 5/10


This series surprisingly offers some unique aspects that almost made it a good show overall. It’s unfortunate that the negatives bring down the strong moments. Even so, it still manages to succeed on levels other popular shonen fail at.


It provides for some serviceable entertainment. The middle part dragged a bit and the last couple of episodes fell flat. It is still an okay show overall. Watch the dub, bask in the awesome OST and appreciate a few twists on common shonen tropes. Just try not to let other clichés, cardboard cutout characters and a grating subtitled protagonist bother you too much. Though that might prove difficult at times.


Overall- 5/10 



Pros:

+A few unique twists on common tropes, both in story and characterization

+Most of the story plays out quickly and fluidly

+Great OST

+Respectable Dub


Cons:

-Most characters are cardboard cutouts of common archetypes

-Multiple cliché’s in the story

-Protagonist’s voice in subtitles is grating
